part.partName: woody, stalkless, upright, brownish yellow, 4 - 7 cm long, oblong-conical, curved; scales without prickles and thickest at the apex. The cones remain closed for many years or until fire opens them (serotinous). Seeds blackish, 3 mm long, triangular, with wings about 10 mm long.
part.partText: deep purple, small, spherical, at tips of last year’s shoots in upper and mid-crown. Pollination between cones occurs from early May to early June.

similarSpecies.comments: Pinus banksiana is best identified by its short, stiff, yellowish green needles in clusters of two, and its curved, closed seed cones which persist on the tree with open cones. Pinus pungens has slightly longer (5 - 10 cm), bluish green needles and heavy, egg-shaped seed cones with thick, prickled scales. Pinus sylvestris has distinctly orange-brown bark in the mid and upper trunk, bluish green needles, and egg-shaped seed cones with scales that thicken at the apex into a 4-sided, unarmed point. Pinus virginiana has soft, flexible, dark green needles and reddish brown, egg-shaped seed cones armed with a long prickle.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Seldom occurs far from lake Michigan, usually in areas with a history of fire. Found in foredunes and higher, more mature dune areas in dry woodlands, but is most common around the edges of interdunal ponds behind the first major dunes (pannes).

notes.comments: Pinus banksiana is a fire-adapted species; heat from fire enables the serotinous, resin-bonded cones to open, and the seeds germinate on the denuded ground. The wood is used for fence posts, railroad ties, pulp, fuel, and boxes.

etymology.comments: Pinus is the Latin word for pine. Banksiana refers to and honors Sir Joseph Banks (1743-1820), a distinguished botanist.
